awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Evaluating the Uptake of Research-Brase Instructional Strategies in Undergraduate Chemistry, Mathematics, & Physics
awd_abstract_narration:
It is well documented that the use of Research-Based Instructional Strategies (RBIS) significantly improves learning and retention of students in undergraduate courses in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM). Yet, there are few large-scale efforts to document the use of RBIS and to explain why they are not more widely used by STEM faculty. This project aims to fill the knowledge gap by examining the use of RBIS and identifying factors that influence implementation of RBIS in undergraduate STEM education. During Phase I of the study, the project team will survey faculty who teach introductory STEM courses in mathematics (Calculus I & II), Chemistry (General Chemistry), and Physics (Introductory Quantitative Physics). The faculty will include people from four types of institutions (associate's colleges, baccalaureate colleges, master's colleges, and doctoral universities). During Phase II, a subset of survey respondents will be invited to participate in interviews that are designed to investigate important themes identified in the survey. The primary aims of the research project are to (1) build capacity to document changes in the implementation of RBIS; (2) estimate the importance of individuals, departments, institutions, and disciplines in shaping instructional decisions to implement RBIS; and (3) test a set of hypotheses on how and why instructors use RBIS. 

The national survey followed by in-depth interviews will establish baseline data for mathematics and chemistry faculty, and will provide an updated and extended snapshot following a 2008 survey of physics faculty. Based on the nested structure of the data, hierarchical linear modeling will be used to examine the quantitative survey data. Qualitative interview data will be analyzed to identify the individual factors, themes, or patterns of factors influencing the implementation of RBIS. The design is well-suited for explaining the quantitative significance (or non-significance) of the results and for providing a more nuanced, qualitative understanding of the implementation of RBIS and reasons for their use across STEM disciplines and types of institutions.

por.por_cntn:
This project generated three data sets. Phase 1 (national survey about teaching context and practices) was completed in Spring 2019. In total, 3769 recent instructors of general chemistry, introductory physics, and single-variable calculus completed the survey. Phase 2 (interviews)  was completed in 2020, We collected 29 interviews spanning 18 high use departments from chemistry, math, and physics.  Phase 3 (national survey about DEI attitudes) was completed in the Fall of 2020. In total we received 1,064 responses to the DEI survey. Responses to this survey provide information on respondents’ professional identity and context, assumptions about the experiences of others in STEM, their beliefs about and engagement with efforts to increase diversity in their fields, and their departmental and personal experiences with discrimination. 

Our analysis showed the impact of: (a) class size, in that very large classes use more lecture; (b) classroom setup, in that traditional classrooms use more lecture than ones built for active learning; (c) experiences as a student, in that instructors who took classes taught using RBIS use less lecture than those who did not; and (d) research activity, in that instructors with very high research productivity lecture more than others. Mixed results came from an investigation of the role of student evaluations: when assessment of teaching effectiveness is important, instructors at institutions with less emphasis on student evaluations report more active learning. We found no evidence of impact on teaching practices based on the instructor’s security of employment (e.g., tenure status). These findings have implications for institutional priority-setting in service of increasing the use of RBIS in undergraduate courses.

Our analysis suggests that classroom space (i.e., conducive to group work or not), participation in scholarship of teaching and learning/discipline-based education research activities, and participation in teaching-related workshops have the largest association with decreased time lecturing. Results from this study support the role of personal and contextual factors in choices to enact active learning pedagogies. Recommendations are offered for how instructional faculty members and institutional leaders can justify and argue for physical and structural changes that support pedagogical reforms.

Using a grounded-theory approach, we developed a Model of Factors and Cycles Contributing to a Department’s High-Use of Active Learning in Introductory Courses from interview data. The model has five main elements: Motivated People, Knowledge about active learning, Opportunities, Cultures and Structures that support active learning, and High-Use of Active Learning in Introductory Courses. There is an iterative and positively reinforcing cycle between people motivated to increase active learning use and departmental and institutional cultures and structures that promote active learning use. The motivated people help develop and enhance a culture and structures supportive of active learning, and in turn the culture and structures help to grow the number of people motivated to reform the teaching of intro courses in their department. Importantly, the motivated people have knowledge of research-based instructional strategies and the results from discipline-based education research. They leverage opportunities, both internal and external to their department and institution, to increase the active learning used in introductory courses in their department. Together, the cycle between people and cultures leads to high-use of active learning in introductory courses in the department, and this becomes established as part of the department’s culture, thus feeding back into the cycle that promotes active learning use. In the manuscript we provide examples of the model elements and discuss implications of the model for departments wishing to increase their active learning use.

Significant results from the DEI survey include (1) many instructors of introductory courses believe black women have less interest in their field than white men. This indicates a significant bias, which may vary by discipline. (2) While roughly 85% of respondents support diversity statements by their departments and/or professional organizations - an action that is primarily performative - only 65% support affirmative action style policies for admissions and hiring in their department - an action likely to tangibly address inequity. (3) When asked if they had witnessed discriminatory behaviors in a professional setting in their field in the last 3 years 53% of chemists, 40% of mathematicians and 46% of physicists said yes. Of those, 66% of chemists reported ever speaking up or intervening in such a situation, compared to 69% for mathematicians and 72% for physicists. This indicates that instructors are frequently recognizing discriminatory behaviors in their field but they often fail to act. Additionally, when we asked those who spoke up about the outcome, less than half felt the discrimination was satisfactorily addressed without negative consequences to them personally. 

A manuscript is in preparation reporting on the current state of RBIS use among introductory physics instructors; this manuscript also includes an analysis of contextual and individual factors that differ among the top and bottom quartile of percent-time-lecturers.
